posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I grew up in the Star Wars EU. I spent 20+ years immersed in it, knowing the how and why to everything that made up Star Wars. It was mine. SW knowledge was my (admittedly lame) super power. And now it's gone. I don't know anything more than anybody else who has seen the movies and it feels like... I don't know. Feels like I imagine a Jedi Master would feel if his connection to the Force just disappeared one day.

It makes me regret the absurd amount of time I spent living in a universe that wasn't my own. I used it as an escape and I shouldn't have. Up until today, I still did. And I shouldn't. I'm 27 years old and I know more about the history of Coruscant than the history of Earth. Or I did, anyway. It's time.

I will see the new movies, passively. When I have time. Maybe I will like them. Maybe my kids will. I always imagined I would be heartbroken if my kids didn't like Star Wars, but right now, in this moment... It just doesn't seem important in the least.

This used to be my universe.

Now it's Disney's "legend".

I can't help but think of all the useful things I could have been reading, could have been passionate about as a child, teen, and adult.

Is it time wasted? Is there a lesson to learn in all of this?

It doesn't matter. I think I'm done here. Those of you hanging on for the next chapter, enjoy the ride. I'm sure it will be great.

The Force will be with you... Always*.

*unless Disney decides it isn't

I'd broadly agree with all of these. It's a stupid person's idea of what a murder mystery is. So instead of carefully placed red herrings, complex alibis, a web of ostensibly conflicting evidence, and a masterful big reveal, it's just asspull after asspull. The audience isn't expected to work anything out - you're just there to sit back as you're spoonfed warm diarrhoea.

Outside of the murder mystery element, a lot of the core concepts in the film don't even make basic sense. In what world would your ownership of a billion dollar company that you've built from the ground up come down to a legal argument about who came up with the idea for the business in a bar? In what world is the fact that someone burned your house down using a clean fuel you've found proof that that fuel is inherently dangerous? The whole point of a fuel is that it's easy flammable. In what world won't the entire world look at the twin sister as a hooligan and criminal for trashing the house, lighting a bunch of shit on fire, and endangering the lives of everyone there by chucking a highly flammable/explosive fuel onto the fire she's built?

That's not why hydrogen gas isn't used at all. The issue with hydrogen is that it's simply not readily available and the costs involved in its production are too high. The industrial processes for producing hydrogen fuel result in more emissions than simply burning coal or gas so not only is it expensive, it's not even considered a clean fuel at the moment.

If we were to develop wind-powered mass hydrogen production facilities, however, it could well become the clean fuel of the future but we're a very long way off realising something like that.

>>178462293
I unfortunately do not know of many whodunits. I have only recently begun to research Agatha Christie and the "whodunit" genre in general, since I am trying to become a writer, and want to understand the history of popular liturature.

However, on the subject of Christie, there have been plenty of delightful adaptations of her works. I haven't seen much of Suchet's "Poirot," but fans of the original books seem to think the series is a good adaptation. In terms of movies (as opposed to TV shows), I also liked the recent remake of "Murder on the Orient Express," though fans of the original work weren't as keen on it (for reasons I found sympathetic when I read them). Nevertheless, I think it is still a good movie.

Finally (I don't know how much it qualifies as a "whodunit" per se), there is the original Robert Downey Jr. "Sherlock Holmes" movie (the first one, mind you, not the second one. The second one's shit). Now critics at the time thought it was bad because it contained way too many action setpieces for a Sherlock Holmes mystery film, and they kind of had a point, but I thought it was fucking kino. It's the ultimate "Enlightenment vs. Romanticism" showdown: basically what the original "Hound of the Baskervilles" story was going for but better. Sherlock Holmes -- our quintessential man of science -- does battle with a fuckin wizard. It may have ripped off some elements from Alan Moore's "From Hell," and obviously the constant fight scenes aren't exactly what you'd expect from a Sherlock Holmes film, but I still think it's one of the GOAT mystery movies
posts.filename: Check Out Some Agatha Christie Too lol

The protostar has three cores:
- Warp Core 1, which powers the ship and normal warp capability.
- Protostar Core, which powers the protowarp.
- Warp Core 2, which powers the containment field keeping the protocore from exploding.

Protostar ships still need dilithium for their two normal warp cores.

The Imperium is actually a progressive place, as far as we're talking gender role. No-one care if you're a man or a woman, you can still die for the Emperor in the Imperial Guard/Navy, you can still become a maegos of the cult of Mars, you can still get your soul sucked out by the Emprah if you're a psyker, you can still become an Inquisitor, be a Noble, etc.

The only place where there are no women are the SM, and that's only because the Emprah wanted to create the biggest baddest around, so he took men and genetically modified them (and also sterilized them). It is pure practicality: bigger muscle mass = bigger transhuman muscle mass at the end. And as all his work was targeted toward men, and the transhuman adaptations are notoriously... complicated and unreliable, of course it doesn't work on women. It barely works on men, the intended recipients, to begin with.

All of this is perfectly logical and from the time when GW writers actually cared about lore. Which is not our time, now, I get it. But the call for female Space Marine is a call that comes from wokeness, without any reasons behind, save for "women are cool and can do anything a man can do but better", which aren't reasons you should base lore policies on.

The A-wing is so bad its propensity for being the fastest coffin money can buy survived a canon revamp through sheer will.

The A-wing, or "How to look cool and die fast" is what happens when A Kuat Engineer snuck into the back of Sienar systems to see the assembly of the first TIE Interceptor and thinking "A cheap fast and basic starfighter with the survivability of wet paper, great! Let's make it faster, let's make it not cheap, let's make it even faster, let's make it without the numbers that TIEs are built around" and his Rebel friend, hearing all this, decides "Yeah we aint got Empire pilot numbers but I sure do like going fucking FAST"

Fast but not easy, you're basically flying two engines strapped to your dick when its just seen two twileks kissing. In a navy that is just full of "I'm the best pilot ever but fuck discipline" jocks there's only one way to compensate for the missing inches of limp-dicked decent piloting and "Well I can fly an A-wing and not die" is there for people who have a hopelessly high rate of optimism and a will already written.

The most famous victory of an A-wing pilot is driving himself into the bridge of a Star Destroyer. This is actually remarkable as it did come at the end of the war between the Empire and the Rebel alliance, since it is frankly fucking AMAZING a-wing pilots survived this long. In the new canon they are given a fresh introduction, and promptly do nothing but fucking explode.

A-wings are the thinking man's suicide note. In a desperate struggle to be the slickest spacer this side of Duros young hotshots sign up for a one-way ticket into either ploughing into the fucking ground, being the first into the fray and into fire in the wet tissue paper tiger, and just generally being the coolest guy in the dogfight because they're already exposed to the vacuum of space.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"Monday's Child" is one of many fortune-telling songs, popular as nursery rhymes for children. The most common words are as follows:
Monday's child is fair of face,
Tuesday's child is full of grace.
Wednesday's child is full of woe,
Thursday's child has far to go.
Friday's child is loving and giving,
Saturday's child works hard for a living.
And the child born on the Sabbath day
Is bonny and blithe, good and gay.
Cartoonist Charles Addams named Wednesday Addams of his Addams Family after this rhyme. The line "Wednesday's Child Is Full of Woe" is the title of the first episode of the 2022 TV series Wednesday based on the character, which also quotes the rhyme in the episode.

>>178455942
>explain his use of text and image and why he used them in the way he did?
Godard often used text, such as intertitles (text that appears on screen between shots), to provide commentary, convey information, or introduce new themes and ideas. For example, in his film "Breathless," Godard used intertitles to provide ironic commentary on the characters and their actions, as well as to provide information about the plot.

> how did he feel about fiction vs documentary?
Godard often blurred the lines between fiction and documentary in his films. He believed that cinema had the potential to be a powerful tool for social and political critique, and he often used his films to explore and comment on contemporary issues and events.

In some of his films, Godard used a more traditional narrative structure and relied on fictional elements, such as scripted dialogue and carefully constructed sets and locations. In other films, however, Godard used a more documentary-style approach, incorporating real-life locations and events and using non-professional actors to create a more spontaneous and realistic feel.

>what was wrong with film to him?
One of the main issues that Godard had with traditional cinema was that it often relied on formulaic narratives and conventions that he believed were uninspired and unoriginal. Godard believed that cinema had the potential to be much more than just a means of entertainment, and he sought to use it as a tool for social and political critique and reflection.

>>178474306
Thank you. So he thinks that with proper technique we can somehow avoid that impact on our thinking? I don't follow.
Case 1: I'm watching ridiculous anime with space vampires. Would Godard feel this is impacting my perception of reality, i.e. the human brain is largely incapable of differentiating fact from fiction once our suspension of disbelief is functioning?
Case 2: I'm watching a documentary about a genocide, but it uses a lot of tracking shots. The impact of what I'm seeing and learning is reduced because I subconsciously view it as "filmic"?
I see the point about the shadows, but it seems that 1) looking at reflections is unavoidable; hell, even in real life you only get small snippets of the entirety of reality at any given point; and 2) I always know it's a movie. I'm not going to genuinely think that the train is going to come out of the screen and hit me, and even if I weep for Leon and Mathilda I'm not going to worry about how she's doing the week after (I think they'll be OK there). Yes, on some level we take lessons from fiction and internalize them, but I don't see how the degree to which that takes place can be significantly impacted by camera technique.
I think a person is more likely to internalize things due to setting (something mundane like Kramer vs Kramer) than something with "non-illusory" techniques used to produce it but takes place on the space vampires' home planet.
I'm probably off-base, but enjoy your sleep.
addendum: Godard uses an exceptionally long tracking shot during the traffic scene in Week-end, and it's one of the more realistic scenes, arguably. I'm just throwing that out there, since I'm not fully understanding the idea yet.

posts.com:
Currently in Japan for vacation, the public channels in the hotels are roughly as follows:

>NHK channel(s): historical shows and dry news
>a couple shopping network channels
>The rest of the channels have either variety shows or variety show "specials" that just focus on a single topic. These are where all the pictures of Japanese TV come from with celebrity reactions in the corner. Different topics or sources of discussion, but almost always features somewhat well-known personalities talking about or taking part in a variety of shit, ranging from cooking, outdoors stuff, board games, seasonal things like giving each other gifts, etc.
For example the show currently on is like some masked singer bit but instead they're in cosplay doing a bunch of different tasks.

Bonus:
>Celebrities react to the news. This is usually uneventful and full of feel-good stories but with the triple murder in north Tokyo last week every time that gets covered it's funny to see the celebrity faces immediately turn sour or disgusted because they know they have the cameras pointed directly at them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178478503
To be fair, you have to have a very low IQ to understand Family Guy. The humor is extremely base, and without a solid grasp on toilet humor, most of the jokes will go under a typical viewer's taint. There's also Peter's moronic outlook, which is deftly woven into his characterisation - his personal philosophy draws heavily from pre-school literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual obliviousness to truly appreciate the shallowness of these jokes, to realize that they're not just funny- they say something dumb about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Family Guy truly ARE well-adjusted human beings - of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the humour in Peter's mind-numbing catchphrase "c'mon Lois!" which itself is a cryptic reference to some dumb bro movie probably. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those hoity toity normies scratching their heads in confusion as Seth McFarland's idiocy unfolds itself on their television screens. What fools... how I pity them. And yes by the way, I DO have a Family Guy tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- And even they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably higher) beforehand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Lesser known movies:

Progeny (1998)
Pretty badly made and unintentionally laughable in parts, bad direction by Brian Yuzna undermines an okay script by Stuart Gordon.
Does a few interesting things with the lore: it turns out Alien Abduction memories are people willfully distorting their true recollections of being raped by giant tentacle brings from other dimensions, who lay their embryos inside living beings to breed
Overall, different but not great

Intruders (1992)
So very long (4 hours) and has some cheesy bits, but overall a very comprehensive run down of all the alien abduction tropes, featuring some very creepy imagery

Roswell (1994)
Somewhere between excellent and utter self-parody recreation of the Roswell crash and its aftermath.
Definitely worth watching once if you're into this kind of thing, possibly the best alien animatronics ever

Visitors of the Night (1995)
The alien stuff is interesting and often well done, but it's mostly a lifetime-type movie about a weak, bad mother and her incredibly bratty teen dealing intermittently with aliens.
God, I wanna slap that fucking kid.
Nice cinematography and pretty cool aliens, though

The Flying Saucer Incident (1975)
Pretty solid TV movie recreation of the Betty and Barney Hill abduction.
James Earl Jones and Estelle Parsons act their little hearts out.
It does mostly turn out to be about how rough it was being an interracial couple in the 60s, with very occasional alien interruption.
Oddly classy, mainly due to the calibre of the actors and the seriousness with which everything is treated.
